reviewText:
Ah the X Series. I haven't heard anything good about rebirth the latest installment to the series but this review isnt about that. X3: Reunion Was the game that turned me on to the whole series. In fact just thinking about it now is making me want to sink even more hours into a title i have already sank more than what would commonly be called healthy gaming. Once you get past the steep learning curve and learn how to fly and fight and trade effectively, this game suddenly turns into how you would want to live in a future that affords you your own space oddesy. Space suddenly turns into your own playground and you become immersed in a universe that is fully dynamic.

With that said i think this title, X3 Terran conflict and X3 Albion Prelude were accidental. Terran conflict takes place after the events of this title, and adds a Major graphics overhaul. And prelude again expands on the story of Terran conflict as well as this title adding features and interfaces that were touched on in this title but done poorly. It is pretty evident the beauty of this game and the other X3 titles is the immersion of the struggle you are put through to learn, and adapt to the changes that happen around you all while getting the sense of achievement from overcoming and growing from the experiences you encounter.

What these games lack is a sense of person however. You sort of create a character or take on a storyline however you rarely interact as that character. You never really see the character and the universe usually refers to you as pilot. In Reunion, the main story you play as julian brennan. working along side Elena Kho. Trying to find your place in the universe. There is an extensive storyline and it all seems to fit very well all things considered.  The other characters however offer a backstory as to why you start out where you do, and how the other races react to you in the beginning.  Ultimately it defines how difficult the game is in the beginning to get started. Once you get on a roll however and you grow all plots start and play out no matter who you play as with the exception of Julian's plot. his has a little more frosting so to speak. Otherwise its all essentially the same. Reunion is also of the three X3 games that has a main character. Terran Conflict and Prelude do not feature main plot character who playing as change the dialogue or offer any additional content.

Pros:
Dynamic Universe - Everything you do or not do effects the universe in some way.
Rich plots - The back story to each of the plots are very compelling and their rewards give a strong sense of achievement
Diverse spacecraft - Each ship has its own classification as well as strength and weaknesses. Even some that are unique and rare.
Races - Each race is unique in its own way and their ships fit the typical role the races engage in.
Fleets - You can build, or buy your own fleet and wage war against anything within the universe, ofcourse doing so will have consquences such as you may end up destroying something you want later. The good news is there is one race you can attack and murder with extreme prejudice and not have to worry about losing a future trading station.

Cons:
Voice acting - Its there but at the time this game was released other studios did it better.
Races - While each race is unique there is nothing unique among their individuals. Humans however occasionally have diversity among males and females but you will be hard pressed telling a male or female split, paranid or teladi.
No planetary exploration. The planets in each system are just there to look pretty it seems.
No station exploration. Each station you only dock at and interact with through the ship.

From what i understand Rebirth attempted at affording planetary and staion exploration however at the cost of starship diversity. Further more these features were not done well and as such losing the ability to fly and construct a diverse fleet was too great of a sacrifice against bland cookie cutter stations.

reviewText:
X3 Reunion is a game of monstrous proportions. Everything in it is vast and massive in a way that's both exciting and daunting. It is relatively easy to get overwhelmed by the sheer scope of the game and the lack of any sort of proper guiding hand to teach you the basic will make many newcomers run for the hills. If you stick it out however you will find that underneath it all is one of the best open space games since the last game from the X series.

Reunion picks up where X2 left off and starts you as Julian Brennan once again. Your trade empire from the previous game destroyed by the Khaak you now have to resurrect it from the ashes, if that's what you want. The story missions available are in true X style utterly forgettable and easily missable. They can even be disabled entirely by picking from one of several sandbox starts this time around.

As always you start you start your adventure in the X universe in a small dingy of a space worthy craft and set about making your mark on the galaxy. How you do this is entirely up to you, you can trade, fight, explore however you like and in whichever forms you want. Some players might want to avoid the fighting aspect entirely and just set up a gigantic trading empire. Others might want to sustain themselves through pirate activity. The beauty of the X games have always been the choice they give you in going what you want to do, you are never forced to fight or forced to trade, it's all entirely up to you how you want to proceed from any given position.

Reunion is not without it's faults however and in this case, it's the bugs top the list. The game was almost completely unplayable at launch and while patches have managed to remove most if not all of the problems it is still not an issue that is so easily forgivable.

Graphically is where the game is truly impressive however, never before has space looked this beautiful and the objects that inhabit it looked this crisp. Every new sector you visit has a sense of uniqueness about it that just makes you want to keep going to see what's in the next one. The ships are beautifully detailed and the background ambient images of stars, nebulae and planets tickle the imagination. This is indeed one stunning visual experience.

The soundtrack is the standard space opera opus that we have heard so many times before, it doesn't detract anything from the experience but it doesn't add anything to it either. Luckily it is easy enough to disable the ingame music and put whatever you feel is appropriate on the stereo. The voice acting you encounter throughout the game, from the missions to your ships onboard computer voice, is downright atrocious however and take you out of the game with an annoying level of certainty.

All in all X3 Reunion is a solid continuation of the X saga, building on the foundations that has remained mostly unchanged since the very first game. Should you desire an open ended space epic then this is the game for you. If you have the stamina to get into the learn the ropes then X3 is as good as it gets, at least until the next X game is released.

reviewText:
An astonishingly beautiful, deeply complex space simulator. The X series have always ruled the economy-based space sim genre and Reunion is no exception. It provides a large universe swarming with life as tons of AI controlled ships each mind their own bussiness and freighters trading wares between stations, affecting the ware prices, which makes the economy quite dynamic and feeling real. Your actions will always have consequences- if you destroy a trader ship, it will not arrive to it's destination and the station will not receive the wares it needs to construct it's products. These were always the core features of X games, just like it's amazing and calming soundtrack, detailed and unique sector backgrounds and intricate 3D models, making it a piece of art. You will notice many tracks ported from the previous X games, aswell as many new ones- my favourite is Home of Light, Kingdom's End and Seizewell sector music.

So what's unique about Reunion, when compared to the other X games? Well to be honest, I enjoyed the older X2: The Threat way more. It's atmosphere was just a bit different, it's interface control was quicker to control, you weren't forced to use a mouse occasionally and could do everything much quicker through keyboard or a flightstick/gamepad (which I really recommend for X3). It's a-life also seemed more detailed as every station had it's set of fighter and freighter ships, each with their corresponding orders. Here in Reunion, everything is replaced with universe traders, which are randomly spawned freighters with commands to endlessly seek the best deals and don't really belong to anyone. After I couldn't find a single station that owns at least one ship, I thought it's a bug. The interface of Reunion is difficult to get around at first and lacks propper organisation. Widescreens weren't so common back then so the windows aren't taking much space either, although there are no issues (except the main menu). There are also no station hangar interiors like they were in X2. Ships now usually dock from outside instead, into a limited number of ship holders. The speed of all spaceships is also reduced so the usage of the time acceleration becomes a must.

Don't forget to visit the Egosoft forums, for mods and gameplay guides. X-Tended Mod (XTM) is probably the biggest one, but if you want to play the X games sequentially and take on Terran Conflict later, then it may spoil you lots of content as it ports most of the ships and stations from it. The cockpit mod is also really good because defaultly there are no cockpits in Reunion, unlike at X2. New Horizons seems like a nice alternative to XTM. Another great mod is CMOD II, which adds more immersive  sounds and Military HUD which.

If you're looking for a good space sim gameplay and don't care about the X story, skip this game and go directly for X3 Albion Prelude. If you haven't played the previous X games before, then Reunion is probably the worst one to start with and I would rather try the X2 for it's in-game tutorial that the X3 games lack. X3TC/AP could also be easy to start with if you don't mind reading some user made guides instead.

Speaking about the whole X series, Reunion is probably the worst one. The only good thing it brought to the series were updated graphics, which can still be called quite eye-candy today. Other than that, it's campaign is is about 20-40 hours long (depending on your X game experience) and I recommend playing it if you want to follow up with the story.

reviewText:
EgoSoft has almost completely redone the interface, but managed to keep the same feel for the game (in my opinion). This 3rd installment is not without bugs however. In fact its probably the most buggy version, with ships crashing into asteroids, gates, stations and eachother at a regular basis (even without SETA), missions (both story and incidental) not loading as intended or not configured properly.

I have come to expect the usual interuptions mid-combat by your employees and wingmen, but in this version they actually tried to do something about it. The interuptions are better planned and the player is put out of harms way when control is taken away, which means that if you die before, during or after a cut-scene or whatever it will probably be your own fault (this time).

The universe has become a lot more vibrant and exciting and the dynamics are just as interesting as they were before. With new weapons, a new generation of craft for all species and new products there is again a lot to explore and learn. reviewText:
Let me start by saying that I really love this game.  It's one of the coolest games I've ever played. You can be whoever you want (within reason) in this beautiful universe.  You can be an industry mogul, managing your company on a galactic scale.  You can be a cop, hunting down bad guys for money.  You can flip that coin and be one of the bad guys, a pirate, making your living by preying on defenseless ships.  You can be a freighter pilot, transporting wares from point A to point B for profit.  You can even be a fleet commander (after you've been playing for awhile), leading enormous space battles and snapping screenshots like a lunatic.  And that's just the beginning, it's set in a living world, where every ship you see is just like you, actually doing something and going somewhere in this massive galaxy and contributing to the intricate, supply and demand based economy.  Be that as it may, it's not for everyone.  If you have a lack of patience, a desire to build a huge empire right off the bat, or you like epic space battles from the word go, then do not buy this game.  If, however, you want to feel like you accomplished something when you do get those things, you want unlimited freedom in space, and you have a RIDICULOUS amount of spare time on your hands, then you will enjoy this.  If you are a busy person with lots of important stuff to do, you probably won't have time to do much in X3: Reunion.  If you are like me, and you have no life, X3: Reunion is the game for you.

The Pros:
+Infinite freedom in space.
+Beautiful graphics that have aged really well (the game was made in 2005).
+Wide variety of ships.
+You can drop in and out of the plot any time you like.
+Realistic economy based on supply and demand.
+Build your own space stations to further populate the universe.
+Be the space trucker of your dreams.
+Buy and sell space drugs.
+Buy and sell space moonshine.
+Buy and sell other goods in a black market as large as the legit one.
+Persistent reputation that affects how you will be received by the locals.
+Trade, fight, cheat, and steal your way to the top.

The Cons:
-REEEEALLY steep learning curve, as the game comes with no tutorial.
-Boring plot, but it really doesn't matter because if you are playing an X game for the plot, you're playing for the wrong reasons.
-Starts off unbearably slow (picks up pace later).
-Atrocious voice acting (makes for a good laugh now and again).
-Confusing jargon (a jazura is a year, I think a mezura is a month, but I don't know for sure).
-Terrible writing, bad puns, etc.
-Your autopilot WANTS TO KILL YOU.
-This game is highly addictive, and you will probably lose friends over it.

In conclusion, X3: Reunion is one of the best games I've ever played, and I will probably never sleep again.  My social life as I know it is over.  It's an absolutely fantastic game, but don't take my word for it, play it yourself and make your own opinion about it.

11/10 would be a space trucker again.
